subject: Design
title: The Parthenon's Optical Illusions
description: A quick, practical guide to The Parthenon's Optical Illusions.

hook.text: The Parthenon looks perfectly straight. It isn't. Every line is slightly curved on purpose.

buildup.text: Greek architects knew that perfectly straight columns look like they bow inward to the human eye.

discovery.text: They added subtle curves â€” entasis â€” to columns and floors so the building appears flawless.

twist.text: Not a single straight line exists in the Parthenon. Every edge compensates for human perception.

climax.text: The Greeks designed for how humans see, not for geometric truth.

punchline.text: Great design corrects reality to match perception.

quiz.question: Why did Greek architects curve the Parthenon's columns?
